translations.translation: And dark-eyed maidens
And companions with big beautiful eyes
and there shall be wide-eyed maidens,
They will have maidens with large, lovely black and white eyes,
And gorgeous eyed fair maidens.
And (there will be) Hur with wide lovely eyes.
And pure, beautiful ones,
and wide-eyed houris
And (there are) fair ones with wide, lovely eyes,
and fair maidens with large, lustrous eyes
And there will be fair ones large eyed.
and big-eyed houris
And (there will be) Companions with beautiful, big, and lustrous eyes,-
And (there will be) Houris (fair females) with wide, lovely eyes (as wives for the pious),
And wideeyed houris
And lovely companions.
And [for them are] fair women with large, [beautiful] eyes,

[56:22] and houris, maidens with intensely black eyes [set] against the whiteness [of their irises], with wide eyes (‘īn: the ‘ayn here is inflected with a kasra instead of a damma because it [the kasra] better harmonises with the yā’; the singular is ‘aynā’, similar [in pattern] to hamrā’; a variant reading [for wa-hūrun ‘īn] has the genitive case wa-hūrin ‘īn)
(And (there are) fair ones with wide, lovely eyes,

commentaries.author: زيد بن علي
commentaries.text:
وقوله تعالى: { وَحُورٌ عِينٌ } فالحورُ: السَّوادُ الحَدقِ
 ويقال الحُورُ: الذي يَحارُ فيهِ الطَّرفُ

translations.translation:
And the saying of Allah, "And {Hurun 'Ainun}", the Hurun here meaning the blackness of the pupil.
 The hoopoe is said to be the one in which the extremity hops.

commentaries.author: الجيلاني
commentaries.text: { وَ } لهم أيضاً للخدمة والمؤانسة { حُورٌ عِينٌ } [الواقعة: 22] مصورة من اعتقاداتهم الصحيحة الراسخة

commentaries.author: ابن عجيبة
commentaries.text:
{ وحُورٌ عِينٌ } أي: وفيها حور عين
 أو: لهم حور عين
 ويجوز أن يعطف على " ولدان " أي: وتخدمهم حُور عين
 زيادة في التعظيم
